title: APRA boss says new bank probe will clear the air on pricing
text:
Mr Elliott said "we know we have not done a good job in explaining our position" on interest rates, while Mr Hartzer described the inquiry as "an important opportunity to put the facts on the table around mortgage pricing".

When pricing loans, banks have to weigh up factors including the the cost of raising deposits and funding from international capital markets and the demands of shareholders for dividends.

“The industry, for right or wrong, has not been successful in explaining to the community how mortgage rates and product prices are set," Mr Byres said. "There has to be a process by which we bring that to a head and put the facts on the table so people can understand them a bit better.”

When it previously investigated banks' explanations for lifting interest rates in mid-2017, the ACCC was critical of Commonwealth Bank, Westpac and National Australia Bank for attributing higher rates to APRA's interest-only benchmark, saying “these banks’ media releases do not necessarily disclose the full story" - including the need to hold more capital against home loans.

Some banks improved the quality of disclosures after the latest October rate cut; for example, CBA pointed to the "difficult balancing act between the multiple, valid interests of our stakeholders" including that "it is currently not feasible to pass on the full rate reduction to more than $160 billion of our deposits which are at, or near, zero rates."

Independence matters

With bankers privately acknowledging the latest inquiry is driven by politics, Mr Byres told the lunch it is important for the government to continue to recognise regulators' independence. He said the concentrated nature of the banking industry and collaboration between key players helped Australia navigate the global financial crisis.

Senior banking sector leaders say it's import Australia's banks remain strong to ensure they can support the economy.

Advertisement

“I believe a strong banking system is essential for our nation’s economic wellbeing," said former Reserve Bank board member Kathryn Fagg, after she was appointed as a non-executive director of National Australia Bank on Tuesday.

Analysts aren't expecting the new inquiry will materially impact on bank earnings, suggesting it's unlikely the ACCC would introduce some form of price regulation to reduce the gap between interest rates paid by new and existing customers - the so-called "loyalty tax" that earns the major banks almost $4 billion in revenue each year.

“The government and ACCC are clearly very focussed on the gap between the front book and the back book. Any forced closing of this gap could have negative consequences for all banks, albeit we still view this as unlikely as it would represent a big step towards price control," said JP Morgan analyst Andrew Triggs.

Don't look backwards

Mr Byres said banks will be capable of dealing with yet another inquiry but cautioned against overloading excessive scrutiny on the sector when it is having to navigate big changes including from new competitors.

“There is no way [the new inquiry] could be described as the straw that broke the camels back or anything like that, but there is a lot of change rolling through the industry, and we have to make sure we are not always looking backwards, but looking forwards at how business models are going to change and technology is going to change the financial system," he said. "We have to make sure we don’t lose sight of those things.”

After APRA deputy chairman Helen Rowell on Monday said APRA will shortly publish "heat maps" of MySuper products' investments and fees, Mr Byres described the initiative as a “step change in transparency” that would "put more pressure on the underperformers to lift their game", while reflecting "a commitment by us to…be seen to be doing something [about underperforming funds]”.

After the damning capability review of APRA by Graeme Samuel, Mr Byres said it has made it a strategic priority "to communicate more and more frequently to improve the understanding of what we do and why we do it."

“Not that long ago we were flagged as the regulator of choice when we were given the BEAR regime. Now we are not the regulator of choice. Everyone will have their day in the sun and their day in the shade. We will just get on with what we think is the right thing.”
description: APRA chairman Wayne Byres agrees with bank chiefs that Rod Sims' inquiry will force facts about mortgage pricing to be put on the table.
